  "article_text": [
    "let @xmath0 denote the subgroup of the smooth three - dimensional knot concordance group generated by the set of all alternating knots .",
    "a simple construction reveals that connected sums of alternating knots , as well as their mirror images , are alternating ; it follows that every element in @xmath1 is represented by an alternating knot .",
    "it has been known that @xmath2 ; in section  [ section : algebraic ] we prove the following result , which also holds in the topological category .",
    "[ theorem : mainalg ] for every positive integer @xmath3 , there is an infinitely generated free subgroup @xmath4 with the following property : if @xmath5 represents a nontrivial class in @xmath6 , then any cobordism from @xmath5 to an alternating knot has genus at least @xmath3 .",
    ".05 in    our main result is this generalization .    [",
    "theorem : main ] for every positive integer @xmath3 , there is an infinitely generated free subgroup @xmath4 with the following properties .    1 .",
    "if @xmath5 represents a nontrivial class in @xmath6 , then any cobordism from @xmath5 to an alternating knot has genus at least @xmath3 .",
    "every class in @xmath6 is represented by a topologically slice knot ; in particular , the quotient @xmath7 is infinitely generated , where @xmath8 is the concordance group of topologically slice knots .",
    ".05 in    these results were inspired by three results concerning alternating knots . in  @xcite",
    ", ozsvth - stipsicz - szab showed that the concordance invariant @xmath9 , a piecewise linear function on @xmath10 $ ] , provides an obstruction to a knot being concordant to an alternating knot . in an earlier paper , abe  @xcite showed that the difference between the rasmussen invariant and the signature of a knot provides a bound on the _ alternation number _ of knot , alt(@xmath5 ) , the minimum number of crossing changes required to convert @xmath5 into an alternating knot . extending these results ,",
    "feller - pohlmann - zentner  @xcite used @xmath9 to find another lower bound on the alternation number .",
    "the work here is built from the key observations of  @xcite .    for a knot @xmath5 ,",
    "let @xmath11 denote the minimum genus of a cobordism from @xmath5 to an alternating knot and let @xmath12 denote the minimum number of double point singularities in a generically immersed concordance from @xmath5 to an alternating knot .",
    "it is straightforward to show that both @xmath13 and @xmath14 induce functions from @xmath15 to the nonnegative integers .",
    "the focus of  @xcite is on bounding alt(@xmath5 ) .",
    "notice that a sequence of crossing changes on a knot yields a singular concordance , and its singularities can be resolved to produce an embedded surface .",
    "thus , a lower bound on @xmath11 yields a bound on @xmath12 and hence on alt(@xmath5 ) .",
    "the approach used in  @xcite leads to much better bounds on alt@xmath16 and @xmath12 than can be obtained via those on @xmath11 .",
    "these will be presented in section  [ section : singular ] , after we conclude our work on the bounds on @xmath13 .    .05 in    in the context of heegaard floer homology , alternating knots form a subgroup of the set of _ quasi - alternating knots_. using the results of  @xcite",
    ", all our results extend to this setting ; our theorems could be stated in terms of @xmath17 , the subgroup of the concordance group generated by quasi - alternating knots , which , by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma  2.3 ) , consists precisely of the quasi - alternating knots .    .05 in _ acknowledgments",
    "_ thanks go to peter feller for his helpful comments and his careful reading of a preliminary version of this paper .",
    "we begin with an elementary result .    [ theorem : alggenusbound ] let @xmath18 be a homomorphism that vanishes on @xmath1 and has the property that for all knots @xmath5 , @xmath19 .",

    "thus , for all @xmath32 , @xmath35 .",
    "( according to  @xcite , this jump function equals the milnor signature  @xcite at @xmath32 . )    to apply these jump functions to study alternating knots , we begin by considering a family of alexander polynomials whose roots have special properties .    for @xmath36 ,",
    "the polynomial @xmath37 is irreducible in @xmath38 $ ] .",
    "it has a unique root , @xmath39 , with positive imaginary part , and @xmath39 lies on the unit circle .",
    "it has two real roots , both of which are negative .    by gauss s lemma , we only need to show that @xmath40 is irreducible in @xmath41 $ ] .",
    "the only possible linear factors could be @xmath42 ; these are ruled out by the condition that @xmath43 .",
    "the only possible quadratic factors are of the form @xmath44 .",
    "the condition @xmath43 constrains @xmath45 to be in a finite set , and one can check the few possibilities .",
    "we can rewrite @xmath46 as @xmath47    by applying the quadratic formula , we see that roots are solutions to @xmath48 in the case that the right hand side is negative , it is clearly less than @xmath49 .",
    "the maximum negative value of @xmath50 is @xmath49 , and from this one can show that there exist two real solutions for @xmath51 , both negative . in the case",
    "that the right hand side is positive , a brief calculation shows that it is less than 2 . since the minimum positive value of @xmath50 is @xmath52 , there are no corresponding real roots .",
    "the symmetry of the polynomial implies that if @xmath53 is root with positive imaginary part , then so is @xmath54 .",
    "there is exactly one root @xmath53 with positive imaginary part , so it must be that @xmath55 and hence , @xmath53 lies on the unit circle .    for all @xmath56 ,",
    "the homomorphism @xmath57 vanishes on @xmath1 .",
    "we use the theorem of murasugi  @xcite stating that alternating knots have alexander polynomials of the form @xmath58 for some @xmath59 and all @xmath60 ( see also ,  @xcite . ) in particular , for an alternating knot @xmath5 , all real roots of the alexander polynomial are positive .",
    "suppose that @xmath61 .",
    "nontrivial jumps in the signature function can occur only at roots of the alexander polynomial , hence @xmath62 . since @xmath40 is irreducible with root @xmath39",
    ", it follows that @xmath40 divides @xmath63 , and thus @xmath64 , where @xmath53 is one of the negative real roots of @xmath40 .",
    "thus , @xmath63 has a negative root , so @xmath5 is not alternating .    by a theorem of seifert  @xcite , there exists a knot with alexander polynomial @xmath40 ; denote some fixed choice of such a knot by @xmath65 . in figure",
    "[ figure : kn ] we illustrate one possible choice for @xmath65 .",
    "the reader may easily find a seifert matrix and compute the alexander polynomial for this knot .",
    "notice that because one band in the seifert surface is unknotted and untwisted , the four - genus is at most one ; since the alexander polynomial is irreducible , it is of four - genus exactly one .",

    "in this section we will consider the count of double points in singular concordances between knots . in the case that one of the knots is the unknot , this is a well studied invariant ; references include  @xcite .",
    "it is known that each of the knot invariants @xmath180 and @xmath95 , remains unchanged or increases by one if a positive crossing is changed to be a negative crossing .",
    "this fact is implied by the following stronger theorem . the proof is related to the proof of the crossing change bounds for @xmath100 and @xmath95 given in  @xcite .",
    "we give the argument for more general invariants .",
    "[ theorem : one - sided ] let @xmath27 be a homomorphism from @xmath84 to @xmath181 satisfying    1 .   for all @xmath5 , @xmath182 , .05 in 2 .",
    "@xmath183 for some knot @xmath23 with the property that changing a single crossing in @xmath23 from positive to negative yields a slice knot .",
    "suppose there is a singular concordance from @xmath184 and @xmath185 with precisely @xmath186 double points , where @xmath187 is the number of positive double points .",
    "then @xmath188    we show that for a knot @xmath5 bounding a singular disk with @xmath187 positive double points and @xmath189 negative double points , @xmath190 this can be applied to @xmath191 to complete the proof of the theorem .",
    "we discuss the case of @xmath192 .",
    "the singular disk can be converted into an embedded surface by tubing together @xmath189 pairs of positive and negative crossing points , and then resolving the remaining @xmath193 double points .",
    "this yields a surface bounded by @xmath5 of genus @xmath187 .",
    "thus , @xmath194 , so we also have @xmath195 , and in particular , @xmath196 .    notice that @xmath197 bounds a singular disk with @xmath187 negative double points as well as @xmath187 positive double points . by tubing the double points together",
    ", we have @xmath198 .",
    "it follows that @xmath199 using the fact that @xmath183 , this gives @xmath200 and in particular , @xmath201 .",
    "this completes the proof in the first case , @xmath192 .",
    "the second case can be proved similarly , or one can apply the first case to the knot @xmath202 .    * note .",
    "* for each of the knot invariants we are considering , the knot @xmath23 can be taken to be @xmath203 .",

    ", title=\"fig : \" ]    for this knot , we compute the difference @xmath216 thus , any singular concordance from @xmath23 to an alternating knot must have at least two singular points . on the other hand",
    ", a result of feller  @xcite implies that this knot has four - genus one , and hence there is a genus one cobordism from @xmath23 to an alternating knot .",
    "two crossing changes convert @xmath105 into an alternating knot ( see , for instance  @xcite ) , so @xmath217 .    in summary , for the knot @xmath218 , @xmath219 and @xmath220 that is , both bounds from theorem  [ theorem : main ] are realized .",
    "there is an immediate theorem , parallel to theorem  [ theorem : main ] .",
    "[ theorem : singular ] for every positive integer @xmath3 , there is an infinitely generated free subgroup @xmath4 with the following properties .    1",
    ".   if @xmath5 represents a nontrivial class in @xmath6 , then any generic singular concordance from @xmath5 to an alternating knot has at least @xmath3 double points . 2 .   every class in @xmath6 is represented by a topologically slice knot ; in particular , the quotient @xmath7 is infinitely generated , where @xmath8 is the concordance group of topologically slice knots .    .05 in",
    "it has been shown that the quotient @xmath7 is infinitely generated ; informally , @xmath221 is small compared to @xmath8 .",
    "it is possible that @xmath222 .",
    "thus , one can ask the following question",
    ".      initially , the only known examples of topologically slice knots that are not smoothly slice arose directly from freedman s theorem  @xcite that knots @xmath5 with @xmath223 are topologically slice .",
    "non - trivial knots with trivial alexander polynomial are not alternating , so this result is probably not of immediate use in resolving question  [ question1 ] .",
    "freedman s theorem was generalized in  @xcite to a class of knots with nontrivial alternating alexander polynomials , offering a possible source of examples , and in  @xcite infinite families of slice knots which are not even concordant to polynomial one knots were constructed .",
    "unfortunately , it is not clear how to use those results to build alternating examples .    .05 in in a different direction ,",
    "litherland  @xcite proved that the set of positive torus knots is linearly independent in @xmath84 .",
    "clearly , they become dependent in @xmath90 , since the torus knots @xmath224 are alternating .",
    "p.  feller , _ optimal cobordisms between torus knots _ , arxiv:1305.2868 . to be published by comm .",
    "p.  feller , s.  pohlmann and r.  zentner , _ alternating numbers of torus knots with small braid index _ , arxiv:1508.05825 .",
    "m.  hedden , s .-",
    "kim , and c.  livingston , _ topologically slice knots of smooth concordance order two _",
    ", arxiv:1212.6628 .",
    "m.  hedden and p.  ording , _ the ozsvth - szab and rasmussen concordance invariants are not equal , _ amer .  j.  math . * 130 * ( 2008 ) 441453 .",
    "r.  litherland , _ signatures of iterated torus knots _ , in topology of low - dimensional manifolds , ( proc .",
    "second sussex conf . , chelwood gate , 1977 ) , 7184 , lecture notes in math . *",
    "722 * , springer , berlin , 1979 .        c.  manolescu and p.  ozsvth , _ on the khovanov and knot floer homologies of quasi - alternating links _ , proceedings of gkova geometry - topology conference 2007 , 6081 , gkova geometry / topology conference ( ggt ) , gkova , 2008 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> there is an infinitely generated free subgroup of the smooth knot concordance group with the property that no nontrivial element in this subgroup can be represented by an alternating knot . </S>",
    "<S> this subgroup has the further property that every element is represented by a topologically slice knot . </S>"
  ]
}
